user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_ClearStubEntry:
```c
static void UT_ClearStubEntry(UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr)
{
    /* Be sure to call free() on any malloc'ed buffers before clearing */
    if ((StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_DATA_BUFFER || StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER) &&
        StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr != NULL && (StubPtr->ModeFlags & UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF) != 0)
    {
        free(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr);
    }
    memset(StubPtr, 0, sizeof(*StubPtr));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UT_ClearStubEntry:
#define UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF 0x1U
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if ((StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_DATA_BUFFER || StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER) &&
        StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr != NULL && (StubPtr->ModeFlags & UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF) != 0)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The code tests and then frees StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, so the pointer refers to mutable allocated memory and must not be const-qualified (free requires a non-const pointer). Declaring BasePtr as a pointer-to-const would be inappropriate here and would force casts when freeing. Therefore Rule 8.13 is not violated in this fragment.
